title: CHICKEN BIRIYANI
text: To make a flavorful Chicken Biryani, start by marinating 1 kg of chicken pieces in a mixture of 1 cup yogurt, 2 tablespoons ginger-garlic paste, 1 tablespoon red chili powder, 1/2 teaspoon turmeric, 1 tablespoon biryani masala, 1 teaspoon garam masala, salt, and lemon juice, along with chopped coriander and mint leaves. Let it marinate for at least an hour. While marinating, prepare 2 cups basmati rice by rinsing and soaking it, then partially cook it in boiling water with cardamom, cloves, bay leaf, cinnamon stick, and salt. In a pan, heat oil or ghee, and cook sliced onions until golden brown, then add green chilies, ginger-garlic paste, and tomatoes until soft. Add the marinated chicken and cook until the oil separates. Layer the partially cooked rice over the chicken, sprinkle with biryani masala, and add more coriander and mint leaves. Drizzle with saffron milk if desired, cover tightly, and cook on low heat for 20-25 minutes to blend the flavors. Gently mix before serving and garnish with fried onions if you like. Enjoy your aromatic and delicious Chicken Biryani!

title: About
text: I’m a second year Computer Science and Engineering student doing minor in Computational Mathematics with a passion for pushing the boundaries of knowledge in AI. With a strong background in Computer Science, my research focuses on Practive Oriented AI, aiming to contribute to meaningful advancements and solutions.

title: My Personal Webpage
text:
Welcome to my personal page! I thrive on solving complex problems and love turning innovative ideas into reality. Whether I’m coding, designing, or exploring new fields, I bring dedication and curiosity to everything I do. Outside of work, I enjoy hiking, reading science fiction, and experimenting with new recipes. Here, you’ll find insights into my projects, interests, and the journey I’m on to make a positive impact in the world. Thank you for visiting, and I hope you find something that inspires you!
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: A sample work
text:
For a demonstration of a line plot on a polar axis, see Figure 1.


Code
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()








Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis
